Yoruba: open your text books to page
English: ẹ ṣí ìwée yín sí  ojú ìwée

Yoruba: báwo ni a ṣe ń sọ wí
báwo ni a ṣe ń sọ ___ ní Yorùbá
English: how do we say ___ in Yorùbá?

Yoruba: would you like to sit down?
I quickly came to say ‘hi’ to you
English: mo kàn sáré wá kí ẹ ni

Yoruba: Káàárò̩ o, Tádé. Ṣé o sùn dáadáa?
English: Good morning, Tade. Did you sleep well?

Yoruba: Bé̩è̩ ni, mo sùn dáadáa. Ẹ ṣé.
English: Yes, I slept well. Thank you.

Yoruba: Kúulé o, Lọlá. Ṣé àlàáfíà ni?
English: Good afternoon, Lola. Are you well?

Yoruba: Ẹ káàárò̩ o. Ṣé dáadáa ni o?
Káàsán o, Ṣadé. Ṣé dáadáa ni?
English: Good afternoon, Sade. Are you well?
Thank you. Are you coming too?

Yoruba: Orúkọ bàbáà mi ni Kúnlé Akínlàjà.
English: My father’s name is Kunle Akinlaja.

Yoruba: Bá mi kí àwọn òbíì rẹ tí o bá délé,
English: Greet your parents when you get home.

Yoruba: Ẹ káàsán o, Màmáa Ṣadé. Gbogbo ilé ńkó̩?
English: Good afternoon, Mama Sade. Is everyone home?

Yoruba: Dáadáa ni o. Bàbáa Fúnmi ńkó̩?
English: They are fine. Is Funmi’s father home?

Yoruba: Wó̩n wà. Ẹ ṣé o. Ó dàbò̩ o.
Káalé̩ o, Títí. Ṣé àlàáfíà ni?
English: Good evening, Titi. Are you well?

Yoruba: A dúpé̩ mà. Ṣé Ṣadé wà nílé?
English: Thank you, ma’am. Is Sade home?

Yoruba: Ó dàárò̩ o, Títí. Kílé o.
I am leaving / I am going
Do you want to wash clothes?
Yes, I want to wash clothes.
English: Bé̩è̩ ni, èmi fé̩ fọ aṣọ.

Yoruba: Olú is not eating pounded yam
I do not want to eat bread
Jò̩ké̩ is not weaving Dúpé̩’s hair
Tún àwọn gbólóhùn wò̩nyí kọ ní òdì.
English: Turn the following sentences into negative.
The egg is eating an egg.

Yoruba: Dáhùn àwọn ìbéèrè wò̩nyí ní òdì.
English: Respond to the following questions in the negative.
Do they want to eat egg?

Yoruba: Myself and others want to eat.

English: Bàbáa Jíde ń gbé ní Ikò̩lé-Èkìtì.

Yoruba: Wonu's mother wants to drink palm wine.
Dáhùn àwọn ìbéèrè wò̩nyí ní è̩kúnré̩ré̩.
English: Answer the following questions in complete sentences.

Yoruba: What do we want to eat?
What do you and he/she want?
English: Kí ni ìwọ àti òun ń fé̩?

Yoruba: What do we and you have?
English: Kí ni àwa àti è̩yin ní?
ẹ ṣí ìwé yín sí ojú-ìwé

Yoruba: Replace the words in bold with possessive pronouns.
English: Fi aró̩pò orúkọ ìní ró̩pò ò̩rò̩ tí a kọ gòdògbò.

Yoruba: we need to review our math
English: ó yẹ kí á tun ìṣiròo wa wò

Yoruba: Mo ri àwọn obìnrin náà lánàá
Àwọn ọkùnrin máa ń dé fìlà
àwọn bàbáà mi ní kí n kí i yín
English: my father asked me to say hi to you.

Yoruba: Write the sentences below in Yorùbá using the plural marker where necessary.
English: Kọ àwọn gbólóhùn wò̩nyí ní Yorùbá. Lo ‘àwọn’ ni ibi tí ó bá yẹ.

Yoruba: Fill out the spaces below with appropriate pronouns.
English: Fi àró̩pò  orúkọ tó bá yẹ dí àwọn àlàfo wò̩nyí.

Yoruba: My name is Wale. I am a student at the University of Texas in Austin. I love my school very much because everything that can make learning comfortable is there, especially in my classroom.
English: Orúkọó̩ mi ni Wálé. Mo jé̩ aké̩kò̩ó̩ ní Yunifásítì ti Texas ní Austin. Mo fé̩ràn ilé-ìwéè mi gan-an ni nítorí pé gbogbo ohun tí ó lè mú kí è̩kó̩ rọ ènìyàn ló̩rùn ni ó wà níbè̩ àgàgà nínú kíláàsìì mi.

Yoruba: There are different things in my classroom. Among them are chair, table, picture, computer, monitor, mouse, keyboard, dictionary, pen, pencil, ruler, eraser, video, CD, file, world map, chalk, chalkboard, and so on.
English: Oríṣiríṣi nǹkan ni ó wà nínú kíláàsìì mi. Láraa wọn ni àga, tábìlì, àwòrán, kò̩ǹpútà, mó̩nítò̩, máòsì, kííbọọdù, ìwé atúmò̩-èdè, pé̩è̩nì, pé̩ńsùlù, rúlà, ìrésà, fídíò, síídiì, fáìlì, máàpù àgbáyé, ṣó̩ò̩kì, pátákó-ìkò̩wé àti bé̩è̩ bé̩è̩ lọ.

Yoruba: Besides that, we can also find other things that make my classroom different from other classrooms in the University, like designed doors, designed windows, electric lights, ceiling, waste basket, and so on.
English: Lé̩yìn èyí, a tún lè rí àwọn nǹkan mìíràn tí wó̩n mú kíláàsìì mi yàtò̩ sí kíláàsì mìíràn ni Yunifásítì bíi ìlè̩kùn aláràbarà, fèrèsé aláràbarà, iná ìlé̩tíríìkì, àjà, apè̩rè̩-ìdalè̩nùsí àti bé̩è̩ bé̩è̩ lọ.

Yoruba: I love my school very much. I also boast about it among my friends because truly, truly, truly, we have it all like the way a woodworker boasts about the wood oil.
English: Mo fé̩ràn ilé-ìwéè mi ló̩pò̩lọpò̩. Mo sì máa ń fi í yangàn láàárín àwọn ò̩ré̩è̩ mi nítorí pé náánní náànnì náánní, ohun a ní là á náánní bí ọmọ aṣé̩gità ṣe ń náánní èpo igi.
The book is on the table.
The keyboard is in front of the computer.

Yoruba: Béèrè ìbéèrè márùnún nínú àwọn ìbéèrè tí wó̩n wà ní Iṣé̩ Ṣíṣe 4 ní ọwó̩ ò̩ré̩è̩ rẹ kan nínúu kíláàsì. Kọ àwọn ìdáhùnun rè̩ sílè̩.
English: Ask your friend five questions from exercise 4 above. Write down his or her responses.

Yoruba: Dárúkọ àwọn nǹkan mé̩wàá tí ó wà nínúu kíláàsì rẹ kí o sì sọ ibi tí wó̩n wà.
English: Mention ten objects in your classroom and provide the location.

Yoruba: Lo àwọn nǹkan márùnún tí ó wà nínúu kíláàsì yìí ní gbólóhùn pè̩lúu Níbo ni…, kí o sì pèsè ìdáhùn sí wọn.
English: Use five objects in this classroom to form questions with Níbo ni… , and provide answers to your questions.

Yoruba: Bàbá Ọlá, ṣé wà á bámi lọ sí oko ní ọsẹ tí ó ń bò̩?
English: Baba Ola, will you go with me to the farm next week?

Yoruba: Rárá o, nítorí pé mo máa lọ sí ọ̀dọ̀ àbúròò mi obìnrin tí ara rè̩ kò yá.
English: No, because I will go to my younger sister's place who is not feeling well.

Yoruba: Tí mo bádé ibè̩, mà á ba lọ sí oko láti mú iṣu, ilá, tòmátò, è̩gúsí, ata rodo, tàtàsé àti è̩gé̩ wá sílé.
English: When I get there, I will go to the farm to harvest yam, okra, tomato, melon seeds, chili pepper, bell pepper, and spinach to bring home.

Yoruba: Tí mo bá dé láti oko, mà á ba se oúnjẹ.
English: When I return from the farm, I will cook.

Yoruba: Lé̩yìn náà, mà á ní láti bá a fọṣọ, lọta, kí n sì bá a gé igi.
English: After that, I will have to help her wash clothes, fetch water, and help her cut wood.

Yoruba: Mà á ba lọ gba oogùn lọ́dọ̀ apòògùn.
English: I will then go to the herbalist's place to get medicine.

Yoruba: Mà á tó̩jú àbúròò mi dáradára.
English: I will take good care of my younger sister.

Yoruba: Mà á dúró tì í títí di alé̩. Mà á wá padà sí iléè mi. Ó dára o.
English: I will stay with her until evening. I will then return to my house.That is good.

Yoruba: Mà á sì lọ sí oko láti hú koríko. Tí mo bá ṣe tán, mà á padà wá sílé.
English: I will also go to the farm to cut grass. When I finish, I will come back home.

Yoruba: Bóyá ti ara àbúròò mi obìnrin bá yá tán a má a jọ lọ. Jé̩ kí á lọ ìsò̩ọ Màmáa Títí. Ìyẹn á dára púpò̩.
English: Perhaps if my younger sister gets better, we will go together. Let's go visit Mama Titi. That would be very nice.

Yoruba: Who is going to his younger sibling's place?
English: Ta ni ó ń lọ sí ò̩dò̩ àbúròo rè̩?

Yoruba: When Baba Ọlá gets there, what will he do?
English: Tí Bàbá Ọlá bá dé ibè̩, kí ni ó máa ṣe?

Yoruba: What will Baba Adé and Baba Ọlá do when Baba Ọlá's younger sibling gets well?
English: Kí ni Bàbá Adé àti Bàbá Ọlá máa ṣe nígbà tí ara àbúròo Bàbá Ọlá bá yá tán?

Yoruba: What is the reason Baba Ọlá will take good care of his younger sibling?
English: Kí ni ìdìí rè̩ tí Bàbá Ọlá fi máa tó̩jú àbúròo rè̩ dáradára?

Yoruba: What will you do next week?
English: Kí ni o máa ṣe ní ò̩sè̩ tí ó mbò̩?

Yoruba: What will you do tomorrow morning?
English: Kí ni o máa ṣe ní àárò̩ ò̩la?

Yoruba: What will you do after finishing your studies at the university?
English: Kí ni o máa ṣe ní ìparí è̩kó̩ò̩ rẹ ní yunifásítì?

Yoruba: What will you do the day after tomorrow?
English: Kí ni o máa ṣe ní ọjó̩ àbámé̩ta?

Yoruba: What will you do during the upcoming holiday?
English: Kí ni o máa ṣe ní ọjó̩ọ ìsinmi tí ó ḿbò̩?
day of not dying (day of rest)

Yoruba: My name is Wálé. I am a native of Ìbàdàn city from Ọyọ state in the country Nigeria.
English: Orúkọ mi ni Wálé. Mo jé̩ ọmọ bíbí ìlú Ìbàdàn láti ìpínlè̩ Ọyọ ní orílè̩-èdè Nàìjíríà.

Yoruba: If it becomes the ninth day of the eleventh month this year, I will turn thirty-one years old.
English: Tí ó bá di ọjó̩ kẹsàn-án, oṣù kọkànlá ọdún tí ó ń bò̩ ni màá pé ọmọ ọdún mó̩kàndínló̩gbò̩n.

Yoruba: According to the story I heard, because a child does not listen to stories, he listens to rumors because rumor is the father of the story.
English: Gé̩gé̩ bí ìtàn tí mo gbó̩, torí bí ó̩mọdé kò bá gbó̩ ìtàn, yóò gbó̩ àró̩bá torí pé àró̩bá ni bàbá ìtàn.

Yoruba: I heard that Tuesday is the day my parents gave birth to me. This makes me happy when my birthday falls on a Tuesday. Regarding color, not to lie, I like color but I do not like red and yellow at all. I like all kinds of food.
English: Mo gbó̩ pé ọjó̩ ìṣé̩gun ni ọjó̩ tí àwọn òbíì mi bí mi. Èyí máa ń jé̩ kí inúù mi dùn fún ọjó̩-ìbíì mi tí ó bá bó̩ sí ọjó̩ ìṣé̩gun. Nípa ti àwò̩, kí n má puró̩, mo fé̩ràn àwò̩ ṣùgbó̩n n kò fé̩ràn àwò̩ pupa àti yé̩lò rárá rárá. Gbogbo ohun tí ẹnu ń jẹ pátá ni mo fé̩ràn.

Yoruba: State whether the following sentences are true or false.
English: Sọ 'bé̩è̩ ni' tàbí 'bé̩è̩ kó̩' fún àwọn gbólóhùn wò̩nyí.

Yoruba: If Wálé’s birthday falls on Tuesday this year, what day will it be next year?
English: Tí Wálé bá ṣe ọjó̩-ìbíi rè̩ ní ọjó̩-ìṣé̩gun ní ọdún yìí, ọjó̩ wo ni ó máa ṣe é ní ọdún tí ó ń bò̩?

Yoruba: Explain what kind of person Wálé is.
English: Ṣàlàyé irú ènìyàn tí Wálé jé̩.

Yoruba: What kind of food does Wálé like?
English: Irú àwọn oúnjẹ wo ni Wálé fé̩ràn?

Yoruba: Do you think Wálé can travel abroad?
English: Ó̩jé̩ ìwọ rò pé Wálé lè ṣe ìrìn-àjò lọ sí ilè̩ òkèèrè?
Kí ni ó máa ń mú inúu Wálé dùn?

Yoruba: What day is the first day of March this year?
English: Ọjó̩ wo ni ọjó̩ kìíní oṣù kẹta ọdún yìí?

Yoruba: What day is the 18th day of April this year?
English: Ọjó̩ wo ni ọjó̩ kejìdínlógún oṣù kẹrin ọdún yìí?

Yoruba: What day is the 21st day of June this year?
English: Ọjó̩ wo ni ọjó̩ kọkàndínlógún oṣù kẹfà ọdún yìí?

Yoruba: What day is the 12th day of August this year?
English: Ọjó̩ wo ni ọjó̩ kejìlá oṣù kẹjọ ọdún yìí?

Yoruba: What day is the 23rd day of December this year?
English: Ọjó̩ wo ni ọjó̩ kẹtàlélógún oṣù kejìlá ọdún yìí?
The first month of the year is January.
The second month of the year is February.
The third month of the year is March.
The fourth month of the year is April.
The fifth month of the year is May.
The sixth month of the year is June.
The seventh month of the year is July.
The eighth month of the year is August.
The ninth month of the year is September.
The tenth month of the year is October.
The eleventh month of the year is November.
The twelfth month of the year is December.

Yoruba: The President of the United States of America
How many books are on the table?
English: Ìwé mélòó ni ó wà ní oríi tábìlì?

Yoruba: There are three books on the table.
English: Ìwé mé̩ta ni ó wà lóríi tábìlì

Yoruba: Aago mélòó ni kíláàsì èdèe Yorùbáà rẹ máa ń bè̩rè̩?
English: What time does your Yorùbá class start?

Yoruba: Aago mélòó ni o máa ń jí lójóojúmó̩?
English: What time do you wake up every day?

Yoruba: Aago mélòó ni o máa ń jé̩ ouńjẹ ò̩sán?
English: What time do you eat lunch?

Yoruba: Aago mélòó ni o máa ń jé̩ ouńjẹ alé̩?
English: What time do you eat dinner?

Yoruba: Aago mélòó ni o máa ń sùn ní alé̩?
English: What time do you sleep at night?

Yoruba: Aago mélòó ni kíláàsìì rẹ àkó̩kó̩ ń bè̩rè̩ ní ọjó̩ àìkú?
English: What time does your first class start on Sunday?

Yoruba: Aago mélòó ni gbogbo kíláàsìì rẹ ń parí ní ọjó̩ Àlàmísì?
English: What time do all your classes end on Thursday?

Yoruba: Kí ni o máa ń ṣe ní aago mé̩ta ò̩sán ní ọjó̩ọ Mó̩ńdè?
English: What do you do at 3 PM on Monday?

Yoruba: Kí ni o máa ń ṣe ní aago mé̩sànán alé̩ ní ọjó̩ọ Jímó̩ò̩?
English: What do you do at 9 PM on Friday?

Yoruba: Kí ni o máa ń ṣe ní aago méje àárò̩ ní ọjó̩ ò̩sè̩?
English: What do you do at 7 AM on the weekend?

Yoruba: Ìwọ àti ò̩ré̩è̩ rẹ, ẹ ṣọ fún ara yín ìgbà tí ẹnìkò̩ò̩kan nínúu yín ń lọ sí kíláàsì àti wí pé kíláàsì wo ni?
English: You and your friend, tell each other what time you go to class and what class you have.

Yoruba: Ládi pe Kúnlé pé kí ó wá gbá bó̩ò̩lù pè̩lú òun.
English: Ládi invites Kúnlé to play soccer with him

Yoruba: Ọpọlọ ò̩dó̩ náà ń ṣiṣé̩ bíi ọpọlọ kò̩lò̩kò̩lò̩
English: The brain of the young person works like the brain of a fox. (S/he is canny like a fox.)
Ọlá threw a spear at the vehicle of his boss.
Bísí helped father take off his shoes.

Yoruba: Híhanrun tí bàbáa Délé ń hanrun jé̩ wàhálà.
English: The snoring of Délé’s father is a problem.

Yoruba: Ìjí jà ní ọjó̩ ọjà ní ìjeje.
English: There was a storm on market day seven days ago.
Jùmò̩ké̩ shook her butt at the dance association.

Yoruba: Kíkéré ni abé̩ré̩ ń kéré, kì í ṣe mímì fún adìẹ
English: Though the needle is small, it cannot be swallowed by a hen.

Yoruba: Mo mu omi ní ilée màmàá Máyò̩wá.
English: I drank water at Máyò̩wá’s mother’s house.

Yoruba: Níyì ná náírà nílé ànaa rè̩.
English: Níyì spent náírà at the in-law’s house.

Yoruba: Pàdé pejò ní pápáa bó̩ò̩lù Àpápá.
English: Pàdé killed a snake on Àpápá soccer field.
Ṣadé fell in front of Ṣọlá.
Títí sold peppers on the street.
Early to bed, early to rise.

Yoruba: Ò̩yàyà ìyáa Yẹmi máyé yẹ é̩.
Ayé yẹ Yẹlé ní ìlú Ọyó̩.
English: Life is pleasant with Yẹlé in Ò̩yó̩ town.

Yoruba: “Iyán l’oúnjẹ‚ ọkà l’oògùn. Àìrí rárá là á j’ è̩kọ‚ K’ẹnu má dilè̩ ni ti gúgúrú.”
English: “Pounded yam is food, ọkà is medicine. Solid pap is a last resort, Popcorn is a snack."
È̩wà jé̩ oúnjẹ tí ó dára láti jẹ
Màmáà mi jé̩ ọmọ ogójì ọdún

Yoruba: Mú fó̩tò ẹbíì rẹ wá sí kíláàsì. Fi fó̩tò ẹbíì rẹ han ò̩ré̩è̩ rẹ, jé̩ kí ò̩ré̩è̩ rẹ gbìyànjú bóyá ó lè sọ nípa àwọn ẹbíì rẹ fún ẹ.
English: Bring a picture of your family to class. Show it to your partner in class, and let your partner guess who the members of your family are.

Yoruba: Nínúu kíláàsì, láláìsí fó̩tò, ṣe àpèjúwe ẹbíì rẹ fún ò̩ré̩è̩ rẹ, kí ò̩ré̩è̩ rẹ náà sì ṣe àpèjúwe ẹbíi rè̩ fún ìwọ náà. Ẹ kọ ohun tí ẹ sọ fún ara yín sílè̩.
English: In class, without pictures, describe your family to your partner, and your partner should also describe their family to you. Write down what you both said to each other.
S/he is neither tall nor short.

Yoruba: Olú ń ṣe àpèjúwe ẹbíi rè̩ nínúu kíláàsì.
English: Olú is describing his family in the classroom.

Yoruba: Sọ lóòótó̩ ni tàbí lóòótó̩ kó̩ fún àwọn gbólóhùn wò̩nyí.
English: State whether the following sentences are true or false.

Yoruba: Lo àpẹẹrẹ tí ò wà ní ìsàlè̩ yìí láti fi dáhùn àwọn ìbéèrè wò̩nyí.
English: Use the model below to answer the following questions.

Yoruba: Lo àpẹẹrẹ tí ò wà ní ìsàlè̩ yìí láti fi dáhùn àwọn ìbéèrè wò̩nyí.
English: Use the model below to answer the following questions.

Yoruba: Wo àpẹẹrẹ tó wà lókè yìí‚ kọ ìsò̩rò̩ǹgbèsì tí ó wáyé láàárin ìwọ àti ìyá ọló̩jà sílè̩. Má ṣe jé̩ kí ó ju gbólóhùn mé̩wàá lọ.
English: Use the example above; write ten lines of dialogue between you and a market woman.

Yoruba: Ṣadé’s mom and Fúnmi’s mom meet in the market.
English: Màmáa Ṣadé àti Màmáa Fúnmi pàdé ní ọjà.

Yoruba: Ò̩ré̩ ni Túndé àti Wálé. Wálé lọ kí Túndé ní ilée wọn.
English: Túndé and Wálé are friends. Wálé visits Túndé at home.

Yoruba: Wálé: Dáadáa ni gbogbo wó̩n wà o. Màmáà mi ní kí n máa kí ẹ.
English: Wálé: They are all fine. My mom said I should greet you.

Yoruba: Túndé: Wó̩n mà ṣé o‚ wó̩n kú àìgbàgbé mi.
English: Túndé: That’s nice of them. They didn’t forget me.

Yoruba: Wálé: Àwọn òbíì rẹ náà ńkó̩?
Túndé: Wó̩n ti jade láti àárò̩‚ kò sì yẹ kí wó̩n pé̩ dé mó̩.
English: Túndé: They left since morning; they should be back anytime soon.

Yoruba: Wálé: Ó yẹ kí n dúró dè wó̩n‚ nítorí pé ó pé̩ tí mo ti rí wọn.
English: Wálé: I should wait for them because it’s been a while since I saw them.

Yoruba: Túndé: Kí ni kí n fi ṣe é̩ lálejò báyìí?
English: Túndé: What should I entertain you with?

Yoruba: Wálé: Èmi! Àlejò? Gbogbo ohun tí o bá ní nílé pátá ni kí o gbé wá‚ mà á jẹ wó̩n. Àmó̩‚ má gbé ògì wá o.
English: Wálé: Me! A guest? Bring everything you have at home, I will eat them all. But don’t bring pap.

Yoruba: Wálé: N kì í mu ògì. N kò fé̩ràn ògì rárá.
English: Wálé: I don’t drink pap. I don’t like it at all.

Yoruba: Túndé: Kò burú o‚ ìrẹsì àti è̩wà ni mo fé̩ fún ẹ jẹ o.
English: Túndé: It’s fine, I will give you rice and beans to eat.

Yoruba: Wálé: Ìrẹsì kè̩! Ṣé kò sí iyán tàbí è̩bà ní?
English: Wálé: Rice? Isn’t there pounded yam or eba?

Yoruba: Túndé: Wálé! O ti fé̩ràn òkèlè jù. Ọmọ ọkà!
English: Túndé: Wálé! You love solid food too much. Except for corn!

Yoruba: Wálé: Ṣé ìwọ ti gbàgbé ò̩rò̩ àwọn Yorùbá tí wó̩n sọ pé: “Iyán l’oúnjẹ‚ ọkà l’oògùn‚ Àìrí rárá là á j’è̩kọ‚ K’ẹnu má dilè̩ ni ti gúgúrú.”
English: Wálé: Don’t you remember the Yoruba saying: “Pounded yam is food, corn is medicine, We rarely eat pap, And popcorn is to keep the mouth busy.”

Yoruba: Túndé: Ó dára‚ mà á fún ẹ lé̩bà.
English: Túndé: Fine, I will serve you eba.

Yoruba: Wálé: Hè̩n-é̩n-è̩n! O ṣé jàre ò̩ré̩.
Nígbà wo ni wà á lọ sí ilé?
Mà á lọ sí ilé nígbà tí mo bá parí ìwé tí mò ń kà.
English: I will go home when I finish with the book I'm reading.

Yoruba: Nígbà wo ni ilé-è̩kó̩ gíga Yunifásítì ti Texas ní Austin ń bè̩rè̩ ló̩dún?
English: When does the school year begin at the University of Texas at Austin?
It’s in the eighth month of the year.
